title: How to Make a Pasta Frame

steps.headline: Gather supplies as noted in the "Things You'll Need" section.
Cut a piece of coloured paper at least 3cm (1.2 in) larger on all sides than your photograph.
Glue the photograph to the center of it.
steps.description: Place the paper on to corrugated cardboard and draw around it with a pencil.

steps.headline: Use the marker pen to draw a line 2 centimeter (0.8 in) in from the pencil along the width of the pasta shape.
steps.description: To mark another rectangle around the pencil line. The rectangles drawn on the cardboard in marker pen form the inside and outside edges of your frame.

steps.headline: Carefully cut out the frame, cutting around the outer rectangle first.
Cover the front of the frame in a thick layer of PVA glue.
steps.description: Arrange the pasta shapes in an attractive pattern on the frame pressing them into glue.

steps.headline: Leave your frame to dry overnight.
Paint your frame, making sure you get the paint into all the corners.
steps.description: Leave the paint to dry, then cover the frame in a layer of PVA glue and let that dry too.

steps.headline: Put a thin line of glue along the outer edge of the coloured border.
Carefully press your picture down onto it.
steps.description: Leave the finished frame to dry.

text: Gather supplies as noted in the "Things You'll Need" section.  Cut a piece of coloured paper at least 3cm (1.2 in) larger on all sides than your photograph.  Glue the photograph to the center of it. Place the paper on to corrugated cardboard and draw around it with a pencil. Use the marker pen to draw a line 2 centimeter (0.8 in) in from the pencil along the width of the pasta shape. To mark another rectangle around the pencil line. The rectangles drawn on the cardboard in marker pen form the inside and outside edges of your frame. Carefully cut out the frame, cutting around the outer rectangle first.  Cover the front of the frame in a thick layer of PVA glue. Arrange the pasta shapes in an attractive pattern on the frame pressing them into glue. Leave your frame to dry overnight.  Paint your frame, making sure you get the paint into all the corners. Leave the paint to dry, then cover the frame in a layer of PVA glue and let that dry too. Put a thin line of glue along the outer edge of the coloured border.  Carefully press your picture down onto it. Leave the finished frame to dry. Finished.
